channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Mayor Says Moscow Has Reached Its Draft Quota
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced what he called a partial mobilization of troops on Sep. 21. Defense officials had said Russia would aim to draft about 300,000 civilians.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Maxim Shipenkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Russian conscripted men saying goodbye to relatives at a recruiting office in Moscow earlier this month.

item.title: Resilient Kyiv Patches Up After Attacks, but Some Things Can’t Be Fixed
item.description: After a barrage of Russian missile and drone strikes on the Ukrainian capital, its residents show a resolve to clean up and press on.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke billows from the site of a drone attack as passengers walk with their luggage from nearby train and bus stations in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: A Military Jet Crashed in Southern Russia, Killing At Least Four
item.description: Russian military officials said the jet was on a training flight when one of its engines caught fire, causing it to crash in a port town about 25 miles from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Randy Pennell
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: The site of a plane crash at a residential building in the southern city of Yeysk, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt Drops Most of U.K. Tax-Cut Plan
item.description: Jeremy Hunt, the new finance minister, dropped almost all of Ms. Truss’s planned cuts, a deeply humbling reversal for Ms. Truss.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Neil Hall/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The statement by Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, Jeremy Hunt, laid bare a government forced into a humiliating 180-degree turn in its economic policy.

item.title: Stock Markets Bounce After a Week of Whiplash
item.description: The S&P 500 rose sharply on Monday after better-than-expected earnings at Bank of America and news of a radically revised tax plan in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti

item.title: Republicans Gain Edge as Voters Worry About Economy, Times/Siena Poll Finds
item.description: With elections next month, independents, especially women, are swinging to the G.O.P. despite Democrats’ focus on abortion rights. Disapproval of President Biden seems to be hurting his party.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The Problem of Marjorie Taylor Greene
item.description: What the rise of the far-right congresswoman means for the House, the G.O.P. and the nation.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.media:credit: Stephen Voss for The New York Times

item.title: Right-Wing Leaders Mobilize Corps of Election Activists
item.description: Officials are prepared for aggressive challenges in midterm elections. “We’re going to adjudicate every battle,” Stephen K. Bannon said.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: An employee sorted boxes of mail-in ballots in Phoenix earlier this month.

item.title: Trump Hotels Charged Secret Service Exorbitant Rates, House Inquiry Finds
item.description: Records obtained by the House Oversight Committee show the former president’s properties charged more than $1.4 million to agents protecting him and his family.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold and Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times

item.title: Justice Dept. Recommends Bannon Be Sentenced to 6 Months in Prison
item.description: Stephen K. Bannon, who is set to be sentenced on Friday, deserved a penalty harsher than the minimum term of one month in jail because he had blatantly brushed off the Jan. 6 committee’s demands, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon, a former top aide to President Donald J. Trump, is set to be sentenced on Friday.

item.title: Half the World Has a Clitoris. Why Don’t Doctors Study It?
item.description: The organ is “completely ignored by pretty much everyone,” medical experts say, and that omission can be devastating to women’s sexual health.
item.dc:creator: Rachel E. Gross
item.media:credit: Ina Jang

item.title: Elizabeth Holmes Case Takes On More Drama Ahead of Sentencing
item.description: The founder of Theranos, the failed blood testing start-up, asked for a new trial after a surprise visit from a key witness to her house.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Elizabeth Holmes arriving her father, Christian Holmes, left, and her partner, Billy Evans, at the U.S. courthouse in San Jose, Calif., for a hearing in her case on Monday.

item.title: An Uptick in Elder Poverty: A Blip, or a Sign of Things to Come?
item.description: Seniors didn’t fare as well through the pandemic as most. But longer-term trends aren’t moving in their favor either.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Mike Belleme
item.media:description: Juanita Brown, 77, has had to do without things like replacing her dentures or replenishing her heating oil.

item.title: Shehan Karunatilaka Wins Booker Prize for ‘The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida’
item.description: The Sri Lankan writer received the award, one of the most prestigious literary prizes in the world, for his second novel, which examines the trauma of his country’s decades-long civil war.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.category: The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida (Book)
item.media:credit: Daniel Leal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Shehan Karunatilaka in London last month. His second novel received the Booker Prize on Monday.

item.title: It’s Not a Diwali Celebration Without Mithai
item.description: South Asian sweet shops across the country are integral in connecting their local communities with their favorite familiar confections.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maharaja Sweets, one of New York City’s most beloved South Asian sweet shops, does brisk business on Diwali.

item.title: A New Playbook for Saving Democracy, Defeating Fascism and Winning Elections
item.description: In the longer contest to tell the better story about America and draw people into that story, there is a great worry among organizers that the left is badly falling short.
item.dc:creator: Anand Giridharadas
item.media:credit: Jon Han

item.title: How Liberals Should Confront a Right-Wing Supreme Court
item.description: The court does not have the only word, or even the last word, on the meaning of the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Fishkin and William E. Forbath
item.media:credit: Illustration by Zisiga Mukulu/The New York Times; images by Robert Alexander via Getty Images

item.title: Why Vladimir Putin Is Likely to Be Disappointed
item.description: None of the Kremlin’s recent gambits will change the battlefield dynamics.
item.dc:creator: Dara Massicot
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ramil Sitdikov/Sputnik

item.title: Imagining a Post-Global World
item.description: The chaos that’s engulfed the economy is driven by a seismic shift toward a better balance between the global and the local.
item.dc:creator: Rana Foroohar
item.media:credit: Illustration by Jordan Awan for The New York Times; photographs by Javier Zayas Photography and dikobraziy, via Getty Images

item.title: Welcome to the Madness of Our Trumpy, Trumpy World
item.description: How much will the Supreme Court change the world?
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Grutter v. Bollinger’s affirmation of affirmative action may well be the next precedent to fall.

item.title: Why We Should All Be Chasing Acorns
item.description: Oaks are keystone plants, the central life form upon which so many other species in the ecosystem depend.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.media:credit: Kristine Potter for The New York Times

item.title: Wait, Who Did You Say Is Middle-Aged?
item.description: Boomers didn’t appreciate getting long in the tooth. But as a Gen Xer, I have to assume it’s worse for us.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Comeback
item.description: Republican leaders have embraced the former political pariah, demonstrating Trumpism’s hold over the party.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times

item.title: The Personal and Political Saga of Herschel Walker
item.description: The Georgia Senate race has become increasingly focused on the private life and alleged hypocrisy of the Republican nominee.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Sydney Harper, Nina Feldman, Robert Jimison, Patricia Willens, Marc Georges, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Lynsey Weatherspoon for The New York Times; Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Raphael Warnock, left, and his opponent, Herschel Walker. Georgia was the closest state in the country in 2020: President Biden won there by just two-tenths of a point.

item.title: The Enduring Appeal of Ronaldo, Soccer’s Original Phenomenon
item.description: The Brazilian striker’s lasting power lies not so much in a deep trove of highlight clips, but in what he showed was possible.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: The Young Women Who Make TikTok Weep
item.description: Songwriters who have found success on the app via emotional catharsis have expanded its range, and piqued the music industry’s interest.
item.media:credit: Jaime Molina for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Opens Applications for Student Debt Cancellation
item.description: The government hopes to help tens of millions of borrowers before federal student loan payments are due again in January.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with Education Secretary Miguel A. Cardona at the White House on Monday.

item.title: Hair Straighteners May Pose a Small Risk for Uterine Cancer, Study Finds
item.description: A national study suggests a link to this particular cancer among women who reported frequent use of the chemical products.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin

item.title: Nigeria Floods Kill Hundreds and Displace Over a Million
item.description: The country is experiencing its worst floods in years, largely because of heavy rains caused by climate change.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Vehicles on an unflooded road in Lokoja, Nigeria, on Oct. 13. The floods have partly or wholly destroyed farmland, infrastructure and 200,000 homes.

item.title: Four Friends Missing in Oklahoma Found Dismembered, Police Say
item.description: A witness had been invited to join the men to “hit a lick big enough for all of them,” or to engage in some kind of criminal behavior, a police chief said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: How to Stay Safe From Covid This Holiday Season
item.description: As our third pandemic winter approaches, you can mitigate risk without missing out.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: How to Get Rid of Bad Breath
item.description: Food choices, oral hygiene habits and certain health conditions can play a role — but there are ways to keep dragon breath in check.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Pablo Delcan; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: Flu Shot: What to Know About Side Effects, Protection and Timing
item.description: And everything else you’ve been wondering about this annual vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: ‘Kind of Awkward’: Doctors Find Themselves on a First-Name Basis
item.description: While many physicians may avoid discussing the subject, a study showed that who gets addressed with the honorific “Dr.” may depend on gender, degree and specialty.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Use of formal titles in medicine and many other professions is a linguistic signal of respect and professionalism,” two doctors wrote.

item.title: Victor Wembanyama Has Always Done Things Differently
item.description: Wembanyama, an 18-year-old with an eight-foot wingspan, will almost certainly be the top pick in next year’s N.B.A. draft. He’s been preparing for the moment for years.
item.dc:creator: Tania Ganguli and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victor Wembanyama, a rising French basketball star, isn’t like anyone else. He’s 7-foot-3, but he’s as smooth as a smaller guard like Stephen Curry.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
